conversation.content: Oh wow, um, I was just thinking about this whole accounts receivable thing again, you know, and it's sort of become this incredible journey of discovery and human connection!

That's definitely an optimistic way to frame what most people would consider the seventh circle of corporate hell, but I suppose someone needs to find joy in repeatedly asking people to pay their bills.
No no no, well, hear me out here, I mean, it's basically like being a relationship counselor but for money and companies and payment terms!
Er, that's actually a fascinating comparison, kind of makes me wonder if, the thing is, you're either a genius or completely delusional about what collections work really involves.
Think about it though, uh, like every [pause] conversation is honestly this amazing opportunity to connect with someone new, to understand their challenges!
Understanding their challenges is one thing, but at the end of the day we still need them to cut us a check, which is considerably less romantic than your vision of financial therapy sessions.
But that's exactly why my approach works so beautifully!
Hmm, I guess your approach does seem to be working, anyway, though I'm still not entirely convinced that treating collections like speed dating is a sustainable business model.
Yesterday I spent forty-five minutes talking to the [yawn] accounts payable manager at Henderson Corp about her daughter's violin recital before even mentioning the invoice!
So forty-five minutes of, uhh, personal conversation before even getting to business, it's just that I'm really wondering if that's efficient, though I suppose relationship building has its merits.
And you know what, err, she actually [very melancholic] apologized for the delay, basically promised payment within three days because we'd become friends!
Well, becoming friends with every client does sound nice, I mean, but sort of exhausting when you consider we have, honestly, hundreds of overdue accounts to manage every month.
Um, but like, that's the beauty of it, right so, once you build that connection, kind of everything flows so much more smoothly!
Ah, I see what you're saying, basically you're playing the long game here, I guess building relationships that, anyway, theoretically make future collections easier and more pleasant.
Exactly! And uh, the thing is, people actually remember you, well, they actually look forward to your calls instead of screening them!
Looking forward to collections calls is like looking forward to dental surgery, but I have to admit your success rate has been remarkably high lately.
Hmm, we should totally do this together, you know, combine your analytical brilliance with my, er, sort of relationship-focused approach!
That could be interesting, though I suspect my spreadsheets might dampen your enthusiasm for turning every invoice chase into a personal bonding experience.
No way, your spreadsheets are [passionately] exactly what would make this perfect because then we'd have both the human touch and the hard data!
Fine, we can try it your way, but if I end up discussing anyone's weekend plans for more than five minutes, I'm billing you for therapy services.
